facts: In many concerts, sound engineers mix the music live using a mixing board to balance vocals and instruments for the audience.
Stage monitors or in-ear monitors help performers hear themselves clearly even when the crowd and speakers are loud.
A concert setlist is the planned order of songs, but artists sometimes change it during the show based on the audience’s energy or special requests.
Applause and cheering can affect how performers play, because musicians often respond by extending solos or repeating a popular chorus.
Large concerts use stage lighting cues and timed effects so that colors, spotlights, and visuals match the music’s rhythm and mood.
Before performing, many artists do a soundcheck to test microphones, instruments, and speaker levels in the venue.
Concert venues are designed with acoustics in mind, and the shape and materials of a hall can make the same music sound different in different places.
